content.title: Aortic Stenosis
content.summary: Aortic stenosis (AS) is progressive narrowing of the aortic valve causing LV outflow obstruction. Degenerative calcific AS is the most common etiology in adults. The classic symptom triad is angina, syncope, and heart failure. Once symptoms develop, prognosis worsens dramatically without intervention. TAVR and SAVR are curative treatments based on patient risk profile.
key_points: Degenerative calcific AS is most common cause in adults; bicuspid valve in younger patients
Classic triad: angina, syncope, heart failure (HF has worst prognosis)
Severe AS: AVA <1.0 cm², mean gradient >40 mmHg, jet velocity >4 m/s
Symptoms mandate valve replacement - medical therapy alone has poor outcomes
TAVR increasingly preferred; SAVR remains option for low-risk patients
Careful BP management - avoid excessive afterload reduction
content.statement: Aortic stenosis is progressive valve obstruction causing LV pressure overload with classic symptoms of angina, syncope, and heart failure, requiring aortic valve replacement (TAVR or SAVR) once symptomatic or severe with LV dysfunction.

explanation.intuition: The aortic valve is like a door that the heart pushes blood through. When the door gets stiff and narrow, the heart muscle has to work harder. Eventually it can't keep up, and blood backs up (heart failure) or can't reach the brain (syncope) or coronary arteries (angina).
explanation.key_insight: The key is recognizing when to intervene: once the classic symptoms develop, survival drops dramatically without surgery - 2-3 years for angina/syncope, <2 years for heart failure. Even asymptomatic severe AS may warrant intervention if EF drops or exercise testing is abnormal.
explanation.technical_details: Calcification of leaflets restricts opening. Chronic pressure overload causes concentric LVH. As AS progresses, the LV-aortic pressure gradient increases. Diastolic dysfunction precedes systolic dysfunction. Low-flow, low-gradient AS with reduced EF is a challenging subset requiring dobutamine stress echo for diagnosis.

definitions_glossary.aortic_stenosis: Obstruction of LV outflow due to narrowed aortic valve
definitions_glossary.AVA: Aortic valve area; <1.0 cm² indicates severe stenosis
definitions_glossary.mean_gradient: Pressure difference across valve; >40 mmHg indicates severe AS
definitions_glossary.peak_jet_velocity: Maximum velocity through stenotic valve; >4 m/s indicates severe
definitions_glossary.bicuspid_aortic_valve: Congenital 2-leaflet valve predisposing to early AS
definitions_glossary.calcific_degeneration: Age-related calcification; most common AS etiology in elderly
definitions_glossary.concentric_LVH: Wall thickening without cavity dilation from pressure overload
definitions_glossary.low_flow_low_gradient: Severe AS with reduced EF and low gradient; needs dobutamine stress echo
definitions_glossary.pulsus_parvus_et_tardus: Weak, delayed carotid upstroke classic of severe AS

pathophysiology.mechanism: Progressive valve calcification/fibrosis causing LV outflow obstruction

degenerative_calcific.prevalence: Most common cause in developed countries

rheumatic.features: Commissural fusion, often with AR and mitral involvement

hemodynamics.LV_response: Concentric hypertrophy maintains cardiac output initially
hemodynamics.decompensation: LV diastolic then systolic dysfunction; reduced cardiac output

symptom_triad.angina: Increased myocardial oxygen demand, reduced coronary flow reserve
symptom_triad.syncope: Exertional; from failure to augment cardiac output or arrhythmia

natural_history.symptomatic: Rapid decline: angina/syncope 2-3 yr survival; HF <2 yr survival

physical_examination.murmur: Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, RUSB, radiating to carotids
physical_examination.carotid_pulse: Pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and delayed)
physical_examination.apex: Sustained, laterally displaced if LV dilated

echocardiography.mild: AVA >1.5 cm², mean gradient <20 mmHg, Vmax <3 m/s
echocardiography.moderate: AVA 1.0-1.5 cm², mean gradient 20-40 mmHg, Vmax 3-4 m/s
echocardiography.severe: AVA <1.0 cm², mean gradient >40 mmHg, Vmax >4 m/s
echocardiography.special: Indexed AVA <0.6 cm²/m² in small patients

additional_workup.exercise_testing: In asymptomatic severe AS to unmask symptoms (carefully supervised)
additional_workup.cardiac_catheterization: If noninvasive inconclusive; coronary angiography before surgery
additional_workup.CT_angiography: Pre-TAVR planning; annulus sizing, vascular access

medical_management.heart_failure: Cautious diuretics; avoid excessive preload reduction
medical_management.hypertension: Treat carefully; avoid excessive afterload reduction
medical_management.contraindicated: Vasodilators in symptomatic severe AS (risk of hypotension)

class_I: Severe AS with LVEF <50% even if asymptomatic
Severe AS undergoing other cardiac surgery
class_IIa: Very severe AS (Vmax ≥5 m/s) if asymptomatic and low surgical risk
Symptomatic patients with low-flow low-gradient AS and dobutamine confirms severe AS

TAVR_vs_SAVR.outcomes: Similar mortality at 5 years for intermediate-risk patients

post_procedural: Antiplatelet therapy (dual or single depending on procedure)

definition.@value: Progressive narrowing of the aortic valve causing LV outflow obstruction with classic symptoms of angina, syncope, and heart failure

scopeNote.@value: Covers etiology, severity grading, symptom recognition, and TAVR/SAVR indications

learning_objectives: Classify aortic stenosis severity by AVA, gradient, and jet velocity
Recognize the classic symptom triad and their prognostic implications
Identify physical examination findings of severe AS
Compare TAVR and SAVR in different patient populations
clinical_pearls: Symptoms = intervention needed; don't wait for EF to drop
Severe AS: AVA <1.0, gradient >40, velocity >4 (remember the numbers)
Pulsus parvus et tardus = weak and late carotid upstroke
TAVR now indicated for most patients ≥65 with symptomatic severe AS
Low-flow, low-gradient AS with low EF: use dobutamine stress echo to confirm severity
common_misconceptions: Asymptomatic severe AS is always watchful waiting - intervene if EF <50% or exercise test abnormal
Vasodilators are safe in AS - avoid in symptomatic severe AS
SAVR is always preferred - TAVR now first-line for many patients
